These two terms and the people who are supposed to represent them are already reconciled. In the modern American sense, liberalism wants progress and a better way of living. In it’s most extreme form, it wants progress for the sake of progress without considering if pushing things forward will make things worse at a practical level. Conservatism wants a better way of living too, but it doesn’t want to make anything worse in the name of progress. In its most extreme form, conservatives don’t want any progress out of fear that things will get worse simply because they are changing. They are not natural enemies. The tension between these two ideas is what forces liberalism to consider whether any particular change might make things worse, and it forces conservatism to consider whether any particular change might make things better. In the hands of rational and sincere leadership, these two sides are already reconciled as having their roles to play. They are both important if they are in balance. But that doesn’t happen in the real world where there’s money to be made and power to be gained by pushing one idea instead of the other one.

When you are driving an automobile, would you rather give up your brake or your accelerator? Would only one pedal work? No, of course not. Liberals are society’s gas pedal. They want action, change, improvement. Conservatives are the brake. They want stability, caution, protection. The country moves forward, not as quickly as liberals would like, and not as slowly as conservatives would like. When you think about it, it’s better that way. You can’t reconcile left and right. You can take positions somewhere in the middle instead of classifying everyone as friend or foe.

I believe that we all exhibit a combination of liberal and conservative beliefs and traits that address our artistic, religious, social, ethical, and political interests and talents. Therefore, those of us who are able to reconcile those personality differences are the healthiest among us. So, I expect that same response applies to our society in general.
